dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s breakfast, there’s a soft hum of conversation. The g windows on one side show off the D.C. skyline. BEN BRADLE (late 40s, articulate but short-tempered) sits with his b against the view. He has a red pencil in hand and reads t draft of a story: “Senate Told Nixon Aid to Laos Illegal” Chryon: June 9, 1971 Bradlee rubs his eyes and looks around the room. There ar MEN scattered amongst the tables reading newspapers. Brad squints to get a better look - every paper is “The New Yo Times”. He frowns and looks back at the story - bored.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Am I late? KATHARINE “KAY” GRAHAM (mid 50s) speaks with trained inte never letting something slip that she hasn’t considered m times over. She’s well put together but not ostentatious.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Mrs. Graham.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I thought we said 8:30.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yes, I was just catching up on a few things. She nods once and sits. A WAITER arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (to Kay) May I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: A cup of tea, please.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Mr. Bradlee?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Thanks, but another cup and I’1l be flying to the office. Neither Kay nor the waiter get it. The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Is there something you wanted to talk about? He reaches into his bag and pulls out a magazine, folded certain page, and shows it to her.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Have you seen this?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Of course. She doesn’t take it as he intended, so now it hangs limpl between them. He reads -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: “Men are more able than women at executive work and in certain situations. I think a man would be better at this job I’m in than a woman.” Did you say that?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It’s an interview with me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: But do you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Do you not?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) It doesn’t particularly matter what I believe - I’m not the Publisher of the Washington Post. She gives a noncommittal acknowledgment. A moment passes. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Well, I’m in a tough position with it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to put a paper together with someone who doesn’t think they should be in charge?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It was implied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, but I disagree.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Forgive me, but that doesn’t particularly matter. I’m pretty sure the consensus is in my corner.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: There are corners?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (sighs) That’s not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Playground fights aren’t going to get us anywhere, Mr. Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s why we’re in a restaurant, not a sandbox. She presses her lips together - a nervous tic she’s never been able to shake. Maybe to stop her from saying somethi she shouldn’t. BRADLEE (CONT’D) We've been getting mail - letters - from women. Asking you to correct your quote. She’s taken aback but covers.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m not so sure that it is.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Well, that won’t be happening. He sighs, a moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to be combative. I... we’re still new at this. She gives him a look.  BRADLEE (CONT’D) The two of us. Working together. As editor and, look, I don’t see a point in letting things fester.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Good. I -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I'd like you to tell me what you’re doing with the Style section. The term “style” comes out as if it has vinegar attached it. He crosses his arms and sits back in the chair - anno

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Is there more than one?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: We're figuring it out.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It’s been a year.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s going to take another.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: We can not keep wasting time on a section that discusses... what is it again?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Fashion, lifestyle, you know - She doesn’t. BRADLEE (CONT’D) My wife likes it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I’m happy for her.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: We can’t drop the “Style” section.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because The Times is starting to print their own.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Good for them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If they run with it and it’s a hit, how’s that going to look? She purses her lips again; he’s exasperated. She pulls a piece of paper from her purse.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I’ve got a quote here, too. (she reluctantly reads) “Ben Bradlee needs a managing editor like a boar needs tits.” He lets out a laugh, a man nearby gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know who sent this to me?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: How many guesses do I get?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Gene Patterson.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Would’ve needed three.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: He'll be stepping down at the end of the year.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What’s he waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I asked him to stay. He gives her a look, clearly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ask for my support, I hire you support, then you terrorize them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Or maybe he just wanted to see if you'd say “tits”?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s beside the point.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: We’re dancing around that aren’t we. (beat) I didn’t terrorize Gene.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: He’s your managing editor.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Was.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: He said you’re not receptive to his ideas.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s not how I’d put it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to trust The Post is doing what it should if you change your mind at every turn?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m not changing my mind about Style.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You changed your mind about Gene.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No, I never wanted Gene. I was clear about that.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (exasperated) I’m trying to work with you, Mr. Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No, Mrs. Graham, you’re not. Gene’s right - I don’t need a managing editor. I need a publisher, you, who is willing to back me, my editors, and my writers.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: How do I not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking the magazine) By saying idiotic things like this! The people around them sneak a peek once more. This isn’t first time Kay’s been scolded, but probably the only time it’s happened from outside her family. Bradlee knows he w too far but he’s too stubborn to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Forgive me, but I don’t know what you want me to say.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: In the event of that, just say nothing. They sit quietly. The waiter arrives with her tea.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Ready to order? This is going to be a long breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee steps onto the street, the bustle of pedestrians commuters on their way to work. He begins his journey thr the maze of D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay climbs into the back of a chauffeured car. Simply, th is something she’s always done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls out into the city and heads in the directio The Post offices. Sitting on the seat next to Kay is the magazine. It’s her own copy. She’s on the cover - regal, sad. The title, “One-on-One with the Queen of the Beltway She frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee edges his way around a small Vietnam protest walk towards the White House, which can be seen off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay reads the article. It’s clear she’s read it many time and is perhaps more insecure about what she said than she on. The car pulls into another underground garage and sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee walks in, his shirt damp from the humidity and wa He throws his copy of the magazine into a nearby trash ca and climbs onto an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open, Kay’s posture straightens, jaw tightens, she steps off. The energy is tense, stiff, quie Along the wall are two portraits: EUGENE MEYER (1875-1959 Kay’s father, and PHIL GRAHAM (1915-1963), Kay’s late husband. They watch over her as she passes to her office the end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee steps off a different elevator and looks across t bullpen: a constant soundtrack of typewriters, the din of news on a TV set, random conversations that come in spurt and starts. He smiles to himself - this is home. The sere lasts for just one moment when -

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I want to ask them about the vets again. MEG GREENFIELD (40s, no-nonsense) instantly annoys him. H doesn’t stop walking.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: They’re throwing their medals into the Potomac and we’re OK with the White House’s “no comment”?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I need you to write something about the protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The United-Women’s-whatever-they’ re- called. Go and... I don’t know. Just get them to not hate us right now.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I take it Mrs. Graham won’t be retracting -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Go away. She grins and heads off as Bradlee approaches his office, handing his briefcase to his secretary, CYNTHIA. BEN BAGDIKIAN (50s, Turkish, resolute) is waiting for him. BRADLEE (CONT’D) (to Cynthia, annoyed) I thought you told them not to hover?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: They don’t listen.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: This is going to annoy me, isn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Have you seen Sheehan around?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Neil? Have we started letting the Times just take up office space here?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: He hasn’t been at the briefings in a while.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What’s a while?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Weeks?  10.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t seen him.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Bagdikian walks off abruptly, as he customarily does. Something about this sticks in Bradlee’s craw.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Get someone to find out what Sheehan’s been up to. Cynthia nods. He heads off down the hallway. INT. GENE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - MOMENTS LATER GENE PATTERSON (late 40s, thinning hairline) reads over s pages. There’s a knock on the door, Bradlee stands there. Gene sighs and sits back in his chair. Bradlee enters.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Did you do it so she’d say tit?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Just an added bonus. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I can’t say that I’m all that disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Nothing but honest.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s not like either of us get anything out of the other being miserable.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You're right on that.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Are you miserable?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It’s been... difficult.  11.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m the “it” in that sentence?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Yes. Bradlee thinks about that and nods.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Graham said you’1l be staying on for a couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: She asked me to.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If you don’t want to, I'll -

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: No, I’d like to see things get sorted properly. Bradlee nods and extends his hand across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: A shame it didn’t work out - I hope you know I respect you. Gene rises and accepts the handshake.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I didn’t, so thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEN MEN sit around a large oval table. At the head is FREDERICK “FRITZ” BEEBE (late 60s, Chairman of the Board, proper and kind) with PAUL IGNATIUS (50s, President of th Washington Post, Co., stuck up) to his right. On his left is Kay - she’s tense in this setting. Her han rest properly on a bound document in front of her. It rea “THE WASHINGTON POST COMPANY INITIAL IPO PROSPECTUS”.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: As you can see, our underwriters have proposed an IPO for a little over 1.35 Million shares of Class B stock. All of the Class A stock will stay within the Meyer-Graham family and they will continue to have the majority vote and right to elect 70 percent of the directors. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Class B stockholders will elect the remainder. There are some murmurs of acknowledgment, a few nods.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Well, I think that’s where my problem is, Fritz. Fritz sighs, he and Ignatius clearly aren’t compatible. K face tightens.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: The majority vote to elect the majority of directors? That feels... one sided to say the least.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Do you have another suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: I just think that perhaps there should be more of a balance. As President, it seems like my voice should be heard, no? The tenor of the room becomes tense, Ignatius keeps a watchful eye on Kay. MARVIN (60s), a boardmember.

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN
dialogues.text: I see where he’s coming from, Fritz. We were elected to the board in order -

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: You were elected by the Graham family.

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN
dialogues.text: Well. I - Marvin shifts in his seat, uncomfortable, eyeing Kay.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It’s alright, Marvin. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN
dialogues.text: Respectfully, Mrs. Graham, I was elected to this seat by your father. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And - I - well, I feela responsibility to keep the company going in the direction he had hoped for.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: And you feel that I’m not doing that?

dialogues.speaker: BOARDMEMBER
dialogues.text: It’s not that necessarily - Kay is surprised by the second opinion. BOARDMEMBER #2 (CONT’D) It’s just. Well. Your appointment happened by... unfortunate circumstances. Because of your husband's, well, because of Phil’s accident. And there’s a standard that The Post - there’s a standard we're used to meeting. Kay purses her lips. Ignatius clears his throat -

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: It’s about the numbers, Mrs. Graham. The revenue from the Post is down by 1% so far this quarter.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: It’s only June.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: And there have been quite a lot of attacks against the President.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Not just by us.

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN
dialogues.text: I understand the President even cancelled his subscription to the Post.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: That was years ago.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: (exasperated) You called him Caligula for Christ’s sake.  14.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I did?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Your editor.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That’s not me.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s the problem.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (indignant) That I’m not the editor?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: That you don’t have control of him.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (heated) What does this have to do with our stock offer?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: It’s more so with the suggested reorganization -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: This company has been owned and operated by my family for 40 years.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Perhaps that’s what needs to change. Kay is stunned, as are a number of people in the room. Ignatius keeps his eyes on hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay slams the proposal onto her desk, furious. Her office tasteful, mid-century modern with personal touches throughout: photos of her children, etc. Fritz walks in a closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Phil always hated them.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: That was a long list.  15.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You seem very relaxed about all of this.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: I don’t know if relaxed is the term I'd use but, yes, I think you’re preoccupied with the negative.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Is there something I’m missing?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (calm) The IPO has been approved. With your shares, the estate’s shares... it’s a good day.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I hate money.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: That’s because you’ve always had it. She gives him a sharp look, but he’s not wrong.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is what the paper needs to keep going. You know that. She nods. Her face softens, the mask of confidence beginn to drip away. A moment passes. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: None of them came to my defense.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: That’s not their style.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Do you think I’m letting them run wild?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Downstairs? She nods, he shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never got involved in Post business. Phil hated it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just seemed... easier for him. He could talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Well, Phil... He loved having the ink stains and all that. Fighting it out. Your father... Eugene liked to be a part but not a player.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Which worked best?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: There were issues with both - the public thought Phil was too involved. Even you've said that. Maybe your father not enough. But both of them understood the difficulties of the post. You have to be able to command the board and the bullpen. (laughing) And neither had to fend with Ben Bradlee in charge.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I thought they would respond to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: The staff. The public.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: I think they do. Do you? She’s not sure. Kay’s secretary, LIZ HYLTON (30s), Fritz rises to leave. Kay nods.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Did they really call Nixon Caligula? He shakes his head, waving as he leaves. 16. enters.  17.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Your daughter called and said she'll meet you at the symphony tonight.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: And Mr. McNamara called. Kay gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a very different looking room than where the Board meets. Bradlee is alone and sits with his feet up on the table, reading through some reports. HOWARD SIMONS (early 40s, stubborn, Bradlee’s right-hand man) comes in.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Are these meetings attendance optional now?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: They’re scrambling. Howard sits next to Bradlee, eyeing him. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How'd that go?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: With Gene.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s Friday, Howard, let’s wait until the blood dries before getting into it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You're going to talk to me though right?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, if no one else shows up in the next five minutes you all might be fired anyway.  18.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Phil’s going to come in here and tell you we don’t have anyone covering Tricia Nixon’s wedding.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: My heart breaks - which Phil?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Geyelin. How many Phils we got?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Why don’t we have anyone covering the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: The White House won’t let us. Bradlee stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Ziegler called and said Haldeman and Nixon didn’t appreciate the coverage from the last event so they’re revoking our press privileges for this one.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Who was supposed to be there?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Judy.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Devastated, I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: She’s been calling for Ziegler all day but he won’t return.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s only 11 am.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: So when'd she start calling?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.  19.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I do and I can’t believe that the most important conversation I’m having with my associate editor is whether Nixon’s daughter’s wedding is going to make the paper this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What do you want -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I want coverage of the goddamn wedding! Beat.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: How was breakfast? Through the glass Bradlee can see Meg, Bagdikian, and a f other EDITORS approaching.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Later. Howard nods. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Well - thank you all for joining us.

dialogues.speaker: MEG BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ben. Sorry. Gene enters with PHIL GEYELIN (40s, balding) and TWO OTHE EDITORS, he closes the door behind them. They all sit.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: Ben, we’ve got a problem with Tricia -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Someone talk to me about anything else first. Meg.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: Ben -

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: The Grand Jury is issuing more subpoenas on the Capitol bombing.  20.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Who are they subpoenaing?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (checking notes) A couple - white collar, middle America.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: OK. Bags, anything from Paris?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: North Vietnamese said they want the US to stop sending aid. The US said no.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: So you'd categorize that as a productive conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh yes, absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: (reading notes) The FBI cleared it’s own funds in congress yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Are they allowed to do that?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: They’re the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (to Geyelin) See if you can get some other papers to share their notes and we'll get our story from that.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: (confused) About the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No. Why, you think the FBI wants to know what Tricia Nixon’s wearing at her wedding?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (sotto) Hoover does.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: I think he means me.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I think we should ignore it.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: The wedding. They’re ignoring us, we might as well ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if poking the bear is the best move right now.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Would we call Nixon a bear?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: He’s more like a little... eh... what do you call them... He scrunches his nose and puts his hands to his face.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: A weasel? Bagdikian snaps his fingers and points -

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Didn’t Herblock make him up like that?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What’re you thinking, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m thinking the reason The Times has a one up on us is because they don’t fuck around calling Nixon a weasel. Everyone quiets down. Cynthia walks in and hands Bradlee note, he reads.  22.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: I heard some Times boys going around talking about printing something that would “end the war.”

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: There were one too many pronouns in that sentence for me to care.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: They say that every other week.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: This about Sheehan?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Nobody’s seen him in the press room in awhile.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean anything, that could just be Neil being Neil.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: You OK, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (reading) Mrs. Graham wanted me to know that she just received a call from the former Secretary of Defense letting her know that The Times will be publishing something “damning” about him this Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What? Bradlee shows Gene the slip.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (hushed to Bagdikian) How’s she know McNamara?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (hushed) She and Phil Graham used to be friends with him and his wife before Phil -  23. He puts his hand to his temple as if he’s holding a gun a pulls the trigger. Meg makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: It’s gotta be about Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Maybe about them pulling out?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That doesn’t feel like a scoop. (to Bagdikian) Could it be that report?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What report? Bagdikian rolls his eyes -

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: There was a rumor a couple years back that some guys were hired by the White House to do a study on Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: What kind of study?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: We couldn’t even confirm that the thing existed.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (to Bagdikian) You talk to Rand?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: A couple times. Nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (tired) Make some calls and see if this “study” has anything to do with -

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t exist, Ben -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Just do it! I’m tired of being ten minutes late to the party! When we meet back in a couple of hours let’s fill in all those “someones” and “somethings” with a few more fucking details.  24. He leaves, Gene and Howard exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee walks toward his office and sees MICHAEL (20s, cl cut) waiting outside. He doesn’t stop walking.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You the runner?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, sir. Michael.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: In. Let’s go. INT. BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - CONTINUOUS Michael follows behind him, he hastily tucks his shirt in his pants. Bradlee gives him a look -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What’re you - you tuck your shirt in while walking into the office?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You looked into Sheehan?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He hands Bradlee a slip of paper. Bradlee looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What’s this.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Um, that’s all Mr. Sheehan has written sir. In the last three months.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Michael nods. Bradlee stares at the boy, lost in thought. Michael shifts in his shoes, uncomfortable. BRADLEE (CONT’D) One article in three months.  25.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Is that... bad?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (sighing) It’s not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beethoven's “Symphony No. 4” is played by the NATIONAL SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA. In a box, Kay watches in her finest n to her daughter, LALLY (30s). The D.C. elite are packed i the thousand; tuxes and studious looks on. While Kay watches the players, others sneak a glance at h the daughter; matriarch; widow; publisher. The attention doesn’t phase Kay - she’s had it all her life. She looks at the Presidential Box. It’s empty. The Symphony finishes, the quiet settles and the crowd li into a roaring applause. Kay snaps out of her stare and politely claps as the Symphony takes a bow. INT. O’BYRNE GALLERY, CONSTITUTION HALL - LATER Champagne glasses clink, the CONDUCTOR smiles for the cam as he is celebrated by a few PARTYGOERS. He laughs, enjoy the praise. He is being watched from outside by -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay. She holds an untouched glass of champagne, encircled a group of people. As if they’re both protecting her and trapping her from getting away. She can’t tear her eyes f the conductor. His seeming joie de vivré.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kay? She snaps out of it and looks to her friend, JOE ALSOP (6 journalist, effeminate), who stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: (light) Now it’s not just my wife, but my closest friends who ignore me.  26. The friends around them laugh, Kay quickly pulls her face back on. With them are ARCHIE, PAUL, Lally. Lally is soci but doesn’t possess her mother’s innate ability to make everyone she’s speaking to feel important.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (teasing) Joe - I could never. I was just so intoxicated by your story I lost myself for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: This woman - always with the witty save in her back pocket.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I keep mine in my purse. Laughs abound from the group, they’re smitten by her.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: I was just saying how sad it will be to not have the Symphony perform here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Have you seen the new pavilion?

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: Only in passing. It’ll have quite the view.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: This one isn’t terrible.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Have you heard what they’re calling it?

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: (nodding) Nixon can’t be happy.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Is he ever?

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Touché.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I was thinking about him tonight.  27. They turn to her, she surprised even herself by saying th out loud.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. Kennedy. Phil and I - we - used to see him in that box often. I was just thinking of how empty it’s been since he’s been gone.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: (sotto) Not a lot of love for the arts with this White House.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if that’s true.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: (to Lally) Oh, we miss your feistiness around here! Kay, tell your daughter she must move back here immediately. Kay smiles and forces a laugh - she’s not going to say th It’s too personal. Lally knows this, she covers.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: But if I come back more often the luster will be lost and you’11l realize I’m only my best in short stints of time.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: That’s what they say about me! The group laughs, Kay looks back to the conductor but, to disappointment, he’s moved on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a very different part of town, Bradlee rings the doorb of a simple home with music coming from within. Standing to him is his wife, TONY (40s, beautiful but tired). His is rumpled. It’s tense.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What's this for?  28.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (distracted) Hm?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This party -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s for Warsh.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I assumed - but what for?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I don’t know - he got an award or something.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You forgot.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Tony, it’s been a long day. He goes to ring the bell again -

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don’t. They heard it. He stops. Annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marina got a B on her History exam.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (absentmindedly ) That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: She was hoping to show you tonight. They’ve had this fight before.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I promised Warsh we'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: For a reason you’re not sure of.  29.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I know the reason I just -

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Forgot.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Can we just get through this and save the banter for home? You know I can’t sleep without the ringing in my ears. The door opens and CHARLOTTE MARCH (40s) answers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: (grinning) If it isn’t my favorite duo. Bradlee forces a smile, as does Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with around 20 PEOPLE milling about. Bradlee heads to a corner where a BARTENDER is making dri and Howard is drinking them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You save some for me?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Never. (to bartender) Two. (to Bradlee) You stag? Bradlee gestures towards Tony speaking to another wife. S couldn’t be less interested.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: She was in a good mood. Once. Howard laughs, Bradlee gets his drink then sees something the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nixon Cheer Squad has arrived. Howard looks as KEN (40s, lanky and balding) enters with wife. Bradlee watches, unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Who’s that?  30.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Lawyer. Works for the party. Had lunch with him a couple weeks back. Spent the entire time talking about Nixon’s new “drug war”.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: When’d guys like that start keeping the secrets?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s always guys like that. Some of them just dress better than others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay’s thoughts are elsewhere but she plays the part.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: But they haven’t invited any women.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIE
dialogues.text: So the women have decided to boycott?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That seems extreme.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Does it? Kay glances at her contradictory daughter.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIE
dialogues.text: The Gridiron’s White Tie.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: What’s so wrong with inviting the women in?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Darling, they’re terrified we'll spill all of your secrets. Archie and Paul laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: If they invited you - you would go, wouldn’t you?  31. Kay is taken aback by the question.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (icy) I’m not sure I’d look very good in a tuxedo. Charming, but cutting. Lally is disappointed by the answe

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: Let’s try it at least!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What would your father say? Kay's eyes shoot to Paul, the tension is immediate.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your father - what would he say if women were allowed? Kay watches him for a moment, her stare impenetrable.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I certainly didn’t speak for him when he was alive so I don’t see a point in breaking the habit now that he’s dead. Paul realizes his misstep, Kay won’t let him back down. Luckily -

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kay? Kay turns to see SCOTTY RESTON (60s, white-templed) stand there, a warm smile on his face. The tension broken, Paul heaves a deep sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Scotty. He kisses her on the cheek. Lally gives him a hug, clearl they all know each other.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joe, you know Scotty Reston.

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: Of course.  32. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIE
dialogues.text: Isn't this crossing enemy lines? The Times and Post on the same terrain?

dialogues.speaker: ALSOP
dialogues.text: Ignore my friends - they live for drama.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Don’t we all. (to Kay) Can I borrow you for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Of course. He takes her elbow and gently leads her away from the par

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you alright? Is Sally?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Yes, yes - nothing like that. He shoves his hands in his pockets. Clearly nervous. SCOTTY (CONT’D) I wasn’t sure if I - I think I should've told you earlier but, well, I hope you understand why I didn’t. I wasn’t sure we were going to print until this morning. The lawyers -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Does this have something to do with the call I got from Bob?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (stunned) McNamara? What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard and Bradlee accept another round from the bartende Bradlee looks at his drink, spinning it absentmindedly.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Everything OK with you? You were pretty on today.  33.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You looking for my confession?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Not drinking enough for that. Bradlee lights a cigarette. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m just tired of losing. And I’m even more tired of weighing everything on whether we lost or not. There used to be a reason for all of this.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: There is. We tell people the truth about things they don’t want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Like every detail of Tricia Nixon's wedding? C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: If you think that then what’s the point?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Because I used to be good at getting a story. Fighting for it. Now I’m just... management. Howard watches him, not knowing what to say. BRADLEE (CONT’D) You know Meyer passed her over for the job once before? Howard gives Bradlee a look. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Instead of leaving her the paper - he left it to Phil. Her husband.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (whistling) Well that tells you something.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It does. I’m just not sure if it says more about him or her.  34.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (quiet) It says that if you want a good party, you call Kay Graham. A paper run? There’s a whole list of names that come first. Charlotte Warsh approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yea, well, we went through those - they keep dying on us. Charlotte taps Bradlee on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: (hushed) Mrs. Graham is on the phone for you.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Speak of the devil and she will - Bradlee shoots Howard a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee picks up the phone. A shopping list is taped to i

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (skeptical) This is Bradlee. His expression changes upon realizing that it’s actually Then turns to anger when he hears what she has to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay hangs up the payphone in the empty lobby - the sounds the party wafting in from outside. She stands there for a moment, processing. Then straightens her posture, puts he face on, and heads back towards the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg, Bagdikian, and Geyelin sit at the table. It’s the mi of the night and they’ve all been dragged out of bed.  35.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: You know what this is about?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Yea, he asked me here at 2am then revealed all his hopes and dreams.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: (quiet) Just asking. Bagdikian chuckles. Through the glass they see the elevat doors open and Bradlee storm out. Howard is on his heels. Bradlee reaches the conference room where a few nearly em coffee cups sit on a nearby table. Bradlee slaps them and sends them flying into the wall. The trio jumps.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Ben! What the -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m getting really goddamn tired of finding out we’re being scooped by the goddamn publisher! Everyone is silenced. In the background, Gene steps of th elevator and sees what is happening. Bradlee pulls out th shopping list - BRADLEE (CONT’D) According to Scotty Reston of the New York Times, they have over “7000 documents detailing how the White House has lied about the Vietnam War for the past 30 years.” Geyelin sits back in his seat, Gene approaches. The night shift in the office gathers to see the show. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Sheehan’s first article comes out Sunday, then they’ll be doing a series about the documents every day. They’re going after the White House with proof that there were ulterior motives from the beginning for sending our guys there. Proof that they lied, that they hid it from the public and that they documented the whole thing. He lets this all settle in.  36. BRADLEE (CONT’D) They’ve been going over the material for three months. Three months. And I had to find out from -—

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: How'd - Meg goes to shush him but it’s too late -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter how she found out! She did it before any of you!

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You’ve got twenty-four hours before the story hits and I’d like to have a little more goddman warning of what it’s going to say than what I already have!

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: (a little forceful) Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What! After a moment, Bradlee takes a breath. He looks back at table - the editors look like puppies kicked when they’re down. Bradlee throws the shopping list on the table and storms out. INT. PHIL’S OFFICE, GRAHAM HOUSE - NIGHT The lights come on, Kay, in her robe, stands in the doorw It’s not dusty, but feels oddly untouched. She steps in, standing across from the large wooden desk. On a bookshel rests a number of framed photos, Phil Graham (handsome, lanky) featured in most of them. One shows he and Kay on their wedding day - youthful, optimistic, but with Kay st carrying a weight on her shoulders. Later photos show him with LBJ, Kennedy, their children, her father, Bradlee. S lingers for a moment. Considering.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lally sits at the table, reading the article from earlier Kay steps in, Lally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Can't sleep? Lally shakes her head. Kay sees what she is reading and frowns, moving to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tea?

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: A moment passes. Kay fills the teapot.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: What time is Yann dropping Katharine off tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: He said 10.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: And he won’t stay?

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: (warning) Mom. Kay offers a thin smile and nods, backing off. She sits w the water boils.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (re: the magazine) I thought I’d thrown that out. No she didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: It’s a... it’s a good article. The page is open to a photograph of Kay laughing with Tru Capote at the Black & White Ball. A different version of than the one in the boardroom - glamorous, in her element

dialogues.speaker: LALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (gentle) I just wish that maybe you'd... take, I don’t know, a little more pride in -  38.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Pride? I can -

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: That’s not the right word. You just - you come across like - I don’t know. You’re in one of the most powerful positions in the country, Mom. And it just seems like... you don’t want it. There’s a lot of people who look up to you.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I think that’s a bit dramatic. The teapot sings, ending the conversation. Kay pours them tea. Lally moves on.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: So what will happen now? Kay gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With The Times. With what they’re printing.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. It’s in Mr. Bradlee’s hands at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: But aren’t you curious?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Of course but it’s not my place to interfere.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Didn’t you get them the story?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You don’t understand how it works. Lally goes to speak but realizes it’s a moot point.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your father always seemed to have the right answer. (beat) At the meeting today. Paul and Marvin, well, they feel that the Board and the trust should share the same voting power.  39. Lally is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: That’s crazy. It’s never -—

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It will be fine. I spoke with Fritz and he’s going to take care of it. I was just... I was surprised. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: (treading carefully) Did they ever... suggest anything like this when Dad was in charge?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. No. Absolutely not. Phil would’ve never stood for it.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: So... why are you? Kay stares at her a beat.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean... I know Dad had a different relationship with them -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yes, of course -

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t you just tell them it’s not going to happen?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That just wouldn’t be appropriate. Lally sighs, exasperated. INT. BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - MORNING Bradlee sits on the phone, same clothes as the night befo Howard across from him. Gene walks in.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Nope. He’s on the phone with a kid from our New York office. Sent them to the hotel.  40.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (into phone) What do you mean you ran away?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Hotel?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: The Times has the 11th floor of the Hilton.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry? Bradlee hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The New York Times is squatting on the 11th floor of the Hilton with two guards standing watch outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Our guys got so spooked they pretended to be lost and ran in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What do you mean ran?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I mean when you go from one point to the other and you don’t walk.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What else did they say?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Not a whole lot. We heard anything from the White House?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: They’ve been busy all weekend. Bradlee gives him a look.  41.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: The wedding.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That fucking wedding.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: All they’re saying is the documents didn’t come from them.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Which we know is bullshit because the only thing that would make this story stick would be documents from the inside. Bradlee checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: So it’s 9am and we’ve got guards outside a hotel room, the White House denying any knowledge of documents that were most likely created inside the White House and...

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: And McNamara’s call. Bradlee stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: The call. From McNamara. This sticks with Bradlee. Bagdikian walks in.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You got something?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) They’re not budging. I’m trying to get a hold of a guy I used to know when I was there. Left a couple months ago and I can’t seem to find him. Ellsberg. Dan.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: He’s kind of a quack isn’t he?  42.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I remember him - he was down here for awhile working on something. Doved real quick.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (absentmindedl]ly ) If the leak didn’t come from the White House, why is McNamara calling us? Bradlee stands, moving towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bags - find Ellsberg.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: To talk to Mrs. Graham, because she seems to be the only one who can get any answers.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: She's not here.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It’s the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Home? Bradlee walks out. Howard sighs -

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That’s going to go well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay sits in an Adirondack chair next to Lally, going over some documents. Her expression one of concern. The grass getting long and unkempt, rising well above the ankles. Playing a few yards away is KATHARINE (5, tow-headed), Ka granddaughter. She runs her hands through the grass, whic now itching Kay. The doorbell rings, Kay’s brow furrows.  43.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Were you expecting someone?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: I'll go check. Lally leaves. Kay looks back to Katharine and watches her play in the yard. A look of concern begins to cloud Kay’s face as Katharine begins to twirl in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Katharine, slow down. Katharine giggles and starts spinning faster, her feet pounding the ground and her arms out beside her.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Katherine, I said stop! Katharine doesn’t hear her, she throws her arms above her head and, in one violent leap, loses her balance and crum to the ground, hidden in the tall grass. Kay is up in an instant, rushing to her granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Katharine! Lally! Lally! Kay approaches, fearful of what she’1ll find where Kathar was once in action. She finds Katharine on her back, gazi at the sky, a look of fascination on her face. Her arms m as if she’s making a “grass” angel. In the background, La runs toward them.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (panicked) Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Look.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You scared me! I asked you to -

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (pointing) Look! It’s red! Kay looks up to the sky and sees the rising moon is a dee red. Kay seems to get momentarily lost in the sight of it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHARINE (CONT’D) Isn't it pretty? Kay looks from the sky to her granddaughter and back agai surprised at the natural wonder of the child. She’s unaccustomed to such unhindered joy and curiosity - somet she’s always kept at bay.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (quiet) It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: (confused) What? What is it? Kay snaps out of the daze.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Oh. It was nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m sorry, I - She looks to the back door and sees Bradlee standing ther

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: He said he needs to ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay hands Bradlee some water. They can see Lally and Katharine playing out the window.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: This is very inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m here. So... Is that your granddaughter?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yes. What did you want to ask me? No small talk is fine with him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea why McNamara called you?  45.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: He’s an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: He trusts me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yes. He waits for more, she doesn’t give it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Maybe I don’t understand the question.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: We’re still piecing together what it is exactly that The Times is printing. We’re not going to get their source in time -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Why not? He’s a bit taken aback. He steams.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Because finding a source is like finding a -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I don’t need a metaphor, Mr. Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Well it’s extraordinarily difficult, Mrs. Graham. I haven’t been a writer in a while so the haystack comparison is really the only one I can come up with right now.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: But if you could get McNamara to talk to us, well, that would be helpful and -  46.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (confused) Talk to you? About what?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: About whatever it is that The Times is printing.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: What makes you -—

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Mrs. Graham, the former Secretary of Defense called you because he knows what’s in that article. He knows what’s in those documents. Which means he either wrote them or organized them or found them. I honestly don’t care which one because he’s one of two people we know of who can tell me about it and the only one whose name I have. She purses her lips.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sorry, Mr. Bradlee but you'll have to find another way.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (stunned) Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Bob McNamara is an old friend who spoke to me in confidence. Not as a source. Not as a subject.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: He spoke to you because you’re the publisher of a newspaper and he was hoping you’d bail him out.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (heated) He spoke to you because he was hoping to get you on his side and banking on the fact that I wouldn’t notice.  47.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I can articulate just how important it is that we get -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You have, but my answer is no. I will not exploit a friendship of over twenty years for -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately that’s the position that you’re in. We exploit friendships and acquaintances and sources to find the information we need because the end is better than the means.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I’m not a journalist, Mr. Bradlee. And I'm not going to change my mind. Bradlee grits his jaw, thinking for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell me I shouldn't go after this story?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That’s not what I -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Because I'll just walk out of the bullpen right now if that’s how it’s going to be. She’s taken aback by his ferocity. BRADLEE (CONT’D) I need to know that you’re going to print these documents if we get them. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (firm) I absolutely will not guarantee that, Mr. Bradlee. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have no idea what is in them, who it might expose, what relationships it could damage if we -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Relationships. He shakes his head and rises. BRADLEE (CONT’D) When we fail, this will be on you. Thank you for the water, I’1l see myself out. He exits, leaving Kay stunned. She looks out the window a sees Katharine twirling in the grass, smiling up at the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln Monument. The Capitol. The White House. A few protesters linger around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagdikian’s desk is empty. In the background, he waits fo the coffee to percolate. He hasn’t slept or left the offi in over a day. There are other people, in other cubicles, have been doing the exact same thing. His phone rings. He doesn’t hear it at first. Finally, he runs over and grabs

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Bagdikian. His mood changes. BAGDIKIAN (CONT’D) Who is this? He seems satisfied with the answer and grabs a pen, writi as he nods his head. BAGDIKIAN (CONT’D) Sure, yes - I’ve got it. He hangs up, grabs his jacket, and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee stands on his front porch in his robe, watching a TWO TRUCKS make their morning deliveries: one for The Tim and one for The Post.  49. He smokes a cigarette and waits for them to drive off. Th he carefully walks across his neighbor’s yard where a Tim paper has been dropped off. Checking to make sure no one him, he grabs the paper and runs back to his porch. He op to the front page and reads, “PENTAGON STUDY TRACES 3 DEC OF GROWING U.S. INVOLVEMENT”. He frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same boardmembers sit at the table. Ignatius has a co of the Times next to him. The tension is palpable. Fritz Kay listen while Ignatius speaks.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: I think it’s clear, after the events of this weekend, that I was correct in suggesting we rethink the voting percentages.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: What does this weekend have to do with that?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: The failure of The Washington Post to properly investigate and report on a story that The New York Times has dedicated the better half of this year to.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Have you read The Times’ article?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: So you'll agree, it’s damning.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Damning?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: To the White House.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Well, it’s -  50.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: And this morning the White House filed an injunction against the Times. It was approved an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: A restraining order. The Times is prohibited from printing anymore of the documents until there is a hearing. Kay smiles, letting Fritz fight for her.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I’m just confused - do you want us to embarrass the White House or stand with them? Ignatius stutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay and Fritz approach her office.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: That’s not going to hold him back - he’1l figure out another way to discredit you in front of the Board.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Can he really take away my voting rights?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (hesitating) Technically no. But he can call a vote to have you removed and that will put into question the -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (stunned) Removed?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: I’m afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: But -  51.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, if Phil wasn’t booted off, you have nothing to worry about. She nods her head - unsure. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You read the article?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (solemn) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (re: the papers) Horrible. The audacity of - I wish I was more surprised. He expects her to respond in unison, but she doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think Bradlee will go after the documents?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It seems that way.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: We can’t get pulled into some kind of legal battle over this, Kay. Not now. It could jeopardize -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (loaded) I don’t think it will come to that.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Let’s hope not. He moves off, she’s more concerned now than ever. She approaches Liz’s desk, there is a stack of letters.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (gentle) More of the letters came in today. Kay furrows her brow and sees a return address on one of envelopes reads: “EQUAL PAY FOR WOMEN”. Kay extends her h

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I'll take them.  52.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Are you sure? They’re not -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yes. Liz hands her the pile and Kay heads into her office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee and a few staffers watch a news broadcast on TV.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: (on TV) Outrage continued today regarding The New York Times’ publishing of what has been dubbed the “Pentagon Papers”. While marches have been steadily occurring in Washington since earlier this year, today saw more pop up in both New York and Boston... Bradlee walks off, shaking his head in annoyance. INT. BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - MOMENTS LATER Bradlee sits in his chair and looks down at a Post story front of him. He reads.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: “As reported by the New York Times.” He sighs and throws a pen at the wall. Frustrated. Angry. There are lots of other little dents in the wall from pen that have been thrown there before. He stares out at the bullpen, mulling over the next move. The elevator doors o and Bagdikian speeds out. Bradlee watches him as he awkwa hurries into his office. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Bags, what the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: I need to go to Boston.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Boston?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: I gotta talk to a guy.  53. Bradlee smiles and closes his office door.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You find Ellsberg?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: He found me. Or, someone we know - it’s not important.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Is he the Times’ source? Does he still have the documents?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: I need to go to Boston.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Alright. (beat) You're still standing here.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: He’s not going to give me the documents unless I promise we'll print them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: We don’t know what they say yet.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Still. I’11 have to say something. Bradlee thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If what’s in these documents is as good as we think, you can tell him that if we don’t print, there’1l be a new executive editor at the Washington Post.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (taken aback) You sure?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Go. Bagdikian nods and leaves. After a moment - BRADLEE (CONT’D) (yelling) Howard! Meg! Get in here!  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagdikian rubs his eyes, the Boston skyline looming ahead roads nearly empty. They pause at a stop sign by the rive The TAXI DRIVER points at a deserted intersection with a payphone.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: You sure you want to go up there? Bagdikian looks up at the street signs, they coincide wit what he has written down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagdikian grabs his bag and shuts the taxi door. He waits the car to leave, then heads to the payphone. He dials.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (into receiver) It’s Bagdikian. Yes, I’m at the corner. Whatever is said doesn’t please Bagdikian. BAGDIKIAN (CONT’D) What the hell do you mean walk to - I just let the cab go! Fine, fine. I’1l be there soon. He slams the phone down on the receiver. Then one more ti to do it right. He starts to walk down the path of the ri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagdikian stands at another payphone, getting more instructions. He hangs up and turns in yet another direct

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark now. A taxi pulls up outside a run down, out-of way motel. Bagdikian climbs out and looks around. He goes one of the rooms and knocks. The curtains move to the sid but he can’t make anyone out. The door opens and DANIEL ELLSBERG (40s, big eyebrows) stands there, an apologetic smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: Ben.  55.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (a sigh of relief) Dan.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: Come in. Bagdikian does. Ellsberg looks around a moment before shutting the door behind him. INT. BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - NIGHT Bradlee sits as his desk reading. His hand toys with his unkempt hair while he notes a few things. There is a knoc the door. He looks up, surprised to see Kay standing ther His mood is icy.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Graham?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: My secretary gave me your note. She holds a slip in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You didn’t need to come down. I just wanted to let you know where we stood. She nods her head once, considering.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: May I come in? He gestures to the chair in front of him. She sits and ta in the sight of the office - she hasn’t been in here sinc took the job. He knows this.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Bagdikian is on his way to Boston?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Should be there by now.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Who is he meeting with? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m not going to tell you that.  She nods - understanding the protection of a source.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You think he’1ll be able to retrieve the documents?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (loaded) I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That's quite a coup.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: We've got good reporters. She purses her lips.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You're going to stay until you hear from him?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It‘’ll be awhile.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Your wife doesn’t mind you staying so late?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: She minds. But here I am.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: And your children? He looks at his watch -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Long asleep by now. Or should be.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Should be and will be are always difficult with children.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Truer a statement has never been made. 56. She looks around, noting the minimal personal touches. On few photos: one of JFK and Bradlee laughing, Bradlee and Graham, and one of Bradlee and a YOUNG MAN (20) in an Arm uniform.  57.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I haven’t been in here since Russ left. Bradlee nods - he knows.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your son? He follows her gaze to the photo behind him. He nods. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: From my first marriage.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Volunteered?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Couldn’t stop him.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Mine too. (careful) He’s, well, he’s home?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Sort of. Peace Corps.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Mine too. Well, not the Peace Corps. But home.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Mrs. Graham?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I thought that we should get to know each other a little better.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I know you.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: As Phil’s wife. An awkward tension enters the room. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you find that difficult?  58.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Excuse me? She points to a photo of Bradlee and JFK.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Being close with the President. Being a journalist and his friend.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Only when someone pointed it out.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Phil never felt... awkward about it. He liked being able to call the President and for him to answer.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: A lot of things were different back then. Beat. Kay’s eyes stay with the photos, Bradlee’s on her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I think my father found personal effects to be distracting, too.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I have some.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Most people have things on their desk though, don’t they? Yours seem to be watching over you.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’ve never thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Of course you have.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: There are a lot of reporters on my staff who don’t ask this many questions.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I wanted to be one once, a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: On my staff?  59. She’s annoyed by his snark. He forces a smile then reache into his desk and pulls out a bottle of scotch and a glas He pours - BRADLEE (CONT’D) If we’re going to do this. He offers her the glass, after a beat she takes it. He finishes his coffee then refills it with liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagdikian sits at a ratty table, Ellsberg opposite him, coffee in front of them both. Bagdikian sees a box in the corner filled with papers.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: Sorry about the rigmarole getting here.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: A lot of guys looking for you. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: How'd you figure it was me?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Sounded like something a crazy guy would do. He’s half-joking. Ellsberg laughs. BAGDIKIAN (CONT’D) I poked around at Rand. They got nervous when I mentioned your name.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: What do you know?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: The basics. You were part of a team set up at the DoD to gather information on Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: (almost wistful) McNamara would say “let the chips fall where they may”. He wanted scholars to have the opportunity to examine Vietnam policy - all angles. I loved it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved the guys - the work. We had access to everything. I mean, how often does that happen, you know?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (treading lightly) But.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: (shrugging) What else... “but” we found something. Bagdikian holds his breath. Ellsberg lights a cigarette, hand shakes. ELLSBERG (CONT’D) None of it was ever about helping Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: What’s it always about? Self- interest. Expansion. Making sure we had the final say.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: But how -

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: It was us. From the beginning: Covert Ops, rigged elections, guaranteed debt. It’s all in there memos, studies, cables. Since the 40s they’ve been doing this. The CIA, NSA, DoD... the White House. 80% of it is classified. They knew all along that we were sending men boys - not to fight, but to die. The knew because they started it all. And they planned it from the start. Then they knew that we were going to lose. But they kept sending those boys over anyway. The truth hangs between them for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: If there’s nothing in there about Nixon - why does he care? He must love how it makes the Democrats -  61.

dialogues.speaker: ELLSBERG
dialogues.text: You think Nixon wants you guys to be able to start publishing materials like this? Nixon may not be in these, but I guarantee he’s got something in a drawer he doesn’t want anyone to find. INT. BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST Kay looks at her drink, swirling it around a bit. Bradlee watches her, arms crossed. Unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Have you thought about it?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: About?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If you're going to let us print these or not. She hesitates. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I don’t know that it’s worth the risk.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You know what I think? She purses her lips - this should be good. Beat. BRADLEE (CONT’D) I think you want to help. I think you're hiding behind your title because you're afraid of making the wrong move when we both know you've spent just as much time in an office like this as anybody.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You don’t like me very much, do you?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I - don’t think my opinion matters -  62.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, it does to me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Why does it matter? I’m -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Call it a woman’s problem.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (scowling) Don’t do that. Don’t bring up the woman thing again.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I am one.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yes. But that doesn’t mean you need to act how a woman thinks a man thinks a woman should act like.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Not the interview again.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I just don’t understand it. You’re running this massive company. All this responsibility on you and... I mean - it’s not 1952 and you’re not running around getting the old boys their coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yet you think it’s appropriate to yell at me about how to do my job.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yes! Because you’re not doing it!

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Would you speak to Phil that way?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I was never in charge of Phil’s -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: If you had been.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Suppositions don’t suit anyone.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Bradlee -  63.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (annoyed, heated) No! I wouldn’t have to yell at Phil about that! I would’ve had to about a dozen other things but not that. Because he would’ve made the call before I even walked in the door. This was his paper. Phil knew that. And he knew that his influence, his opinion, mattered.
