It was the opinion of the Washington Post. And you, Mrs. Graham, your opinion, for better or worse, is the opinion of the Washington Post! If you don’t believe you should be running it, why the hell should I? Kay looks at her glass, the honesty hitting them both. He little embarrassed by his outburst. The moment hangs ther

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: What you don’t seem to understand is that it’s not about what I want. It’s never been about that. It’s about what is right for the paper. That’s what comes first. (beat) That’s what has always come first.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: But can’t you -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I’ve been getting some of those letters, too. (beat) Everyone seems to have an opinion on how I’m supposed to behave. You. The Board. My daughter. I walked around like my father, they’d call me a narcissist. If I behaved like Phil they’d have me committed much -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Well -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: - faster than he was. I’m left with no real option except to let all of this keep spinning while I try to make sure it doesn’t slip off its axis.  This hits The phone 64.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It is slipping. You’re just too busy trying to keep up appearances that you haven’t noticed. her hard. She processes. BRADLEE (CONT’D) I think you want to help. But, that’s what everyone says. rings, startling them both. Bradlee picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bags? (listening) Great. We'll see you in a few hours. He hangs up. She nods He nods. She nods BRADLEE (CONT’D) He’s got the documents. He’s headed back now. and rises to leave.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You'll keep me informed?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I’m throwing Harry Gladstein a retirement party tomorrow night. If I cancel, people will know something is going on. She stops at the door.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think Phil would print them?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (sighs) I can’t answer that. once.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Have a good night, Mr. Bradlee.  65.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Good night, Mrs. Graham. She leaves. He stares at her empty glass for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s early, the morning light casting a beautiful glow on semi-suburban neighborhood. A few extra cars are parked i the driveway and MARINA BRADLEE (11) sits at a table sell lemonade. Trudging along from afar is Bagdikian, the box papers weighing heavily in his arms. He looks awful.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Lemonade? He doesn’t respond or stop; a man on a mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg, Howard, and Geyelin all crowd around the kitchen. To tries to make coffee as quickly as possible but the repor keep gulping it down. Bradlee hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The Times is going to lose their appeal. The mood in the room falls a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens and closes, the reporters peek their heads around the corner as Bagdikian walks in. He drops t box on the ground then goes to the living room and lies o the couch. It’s a feeding frenzy, they grab handfuls of p and start to read. Bradlee approaches Bagdikian.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You OK, Bags?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (eyes closed) Yea. I just - need a minute. Bradlee smiles and smacks him on the shoulder. Meg goes through some pages -

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Wait - are... these in order?  66.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look like it -

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Bags, did you see if they were organized in some -

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: This is how they came to me.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: It’s more than... She looks to Geyelin who, in turn, looks to Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: We can’t sort through this much stuff in time to - Bradlee’s expression quiets him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: The Times had three months, we -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Have nine hours. The editors stare at him. They don’t move.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I think... it’s... it might be -

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: It’s a tall order. In the background, Marina approaches Bagdikian with a cup lemonade. He smiles and reaches for it, she pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: 10 cents. He scowls but reaches into his pocket, she grins.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What? Marina glances at her father - she’s heard that tone befo This is about to get bad. She goes to get more lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: I just -  67.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What does that mean “it’s a tall order”.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: He’s saying -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: He’s saying it’s not worth it. It’s too hard. Why even bother - The Times has done it already. They've got everyone talking so why waste our time.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That’s not -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s exactly what he’s saying! The room is quiet. BRADLEE (CONT’D) For the last six months, hell, for the last two years, we've been taking what they give us and now, when we have something and we can do something about it - no. No. We don’t want to do that. (beat) Because it’s a tall order. (beat) I can’t be the only one who cares about this. Because if that happens I get mad and every else gets fired and we’re all screwed in the end. He goes to the box and grabs a stack of papers then sits begins to sort through them. After a moment, the rest of team does so as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay walks in, looking around for someone. She spots ROBER McNAMARA (50s) sitting at a table by himself, reading the paper, eating breakfast. She approaches. He looks up, surprised, then instantly knowing why she’s there.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: Hello Kay.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Hello Bob.  She takes Beat. 68.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: (resigned) Please. Sit. the seat across from him. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: I’ve had articles written about me before.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Not like this.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: No. Not like this.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Bob -

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: Do you know what I did at Ford?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (puzzled) You were the President, I assume you -

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: All anyone cared about was selling cars. All that mattered was how they looked, how they sounded, how they felt. No one saw a car like I saw it - like a weapon. She’s listening but - where’s this going?

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted them to put in seat belts. But they said, “Well, if you put the seat belt in there, all anyone’s thinking about is their kid’s head going through the windshield.” It didn’t matter that I had mountains of research to prove otherwise. Eventually I got them to put it in as an option.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Bob.  69.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: I thought “At least I got them to do that much.” My conscience could be clear. For the most part. Of course, it didn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: The second I left for Washington they took the seat belts away. People kept dying. But - they kept selling cars. (beat) And they sure looked pretty.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Bob, why did you call me? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: I guess I was trying to give you a seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The journalists have split the piles into different secti Meg and Geyelin are on the floor, sorting things while Ho reads the organized materials. The room is tense. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. He and Meg exchange a look filled with anger... sadness.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: The whole time... when Johnson was running and... he was... She looks up at Howard.

dialogues.speaker: MEG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’d sent the boys over there already. He was acting like it’d never happen but... he’d already done it. Howard watches her, sad. It all sinking in.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee sits at the table, phone to ear, head in hand. Th cord is stretched inconveniently across the room so if an wants to walk in, they have to duck. Tony makes sandwiche

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m still on hold.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: On hold with who?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Who are you on hold with?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The lawyers. Supposedly. Though at this point they could've transferred me to the Guam Embassy and I wouldn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You do that all the time.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Call Guam?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Say something without knowing that I’m here. Howard pokes his head in, getting Bradlee’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yea?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (hushed) Some of this stuff. It’s... it’s heavy. Even just going through it. I’m wondering if we could get Mrs. Graham to come and take a look. Tell us if -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s not her job, Howard.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Then what is? Because we’re sitting here going through all of -  71.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (firm) Go back to work. After a moment, Howard does. Bradlee watches him go. Tony turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: There’s an embassy for Guam?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Of course, there’s an embassy for -— (into receiver) Yes! Yes. This is Ben. Bradlee. Of the Washington. Post. I’m trying to get - He’s clearly put on hold again. He slaps his hand on the table four times - each one harder than the last.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It might help if you were more condescending. Why don’t you just call Mrs. Graham?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Jesus -—

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I was teasing that time. I can tease. No he can’t. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Because if I call Mrs. Graham without knowing what the lawyers are going to say then the first thing she’s going to do is call the lawyers and I’11 be on hold with both of them. At least this one cuts out the middle man.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Except you’re still on hold. He glances over at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What are you doing back there?  72.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Making sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: For who? She stares at him and shakes her head. She puts the sandwiches on a platter and walks out, ducking under the cord. The front door opens - Bradlee turns. He sees ROGER CLARK (late 30s), ANTHONY ESSAYE (40s), and a few other LAWYERS arrive.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Mr. Bradlee?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: We’re from Royall, Koegell, & Wells. Koegell is pronounced “Kegel”.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (to Meg re: Koegell) What’d he say? She would roll her eyes but she’s too tired.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The lawyers?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (irritated) Who the hell am I on hold to talk to then?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Probably me. Bradlee slams the phone down and walks to them -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Your firm needs to work on its communication skills.  73.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: We'll get right on that. He extends his hand -

dialogues.speaker: CLARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Roger Clark. Bradlee shakes it, briefly, and walks towards the back.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: OK. Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Ben - I think we need to get a writer over here. We’re going to need to get someone -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Call Chalmers.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: He’s... not going to be happy about that.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Call him! Bradlee kicks the couch, waking a sleeping Bagdikian. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Bags - with me. He turns and heads into another room. Bagdikian, Clark, a Assaye follow behind. The remainder stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty tea cup sits in front of Kay, a silent tension r between the old friends.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: We have the papers.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be telling me that.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t have called. He nods, conceding.  74.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I haven't decided what we’re going to do with them yet.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I’m the one to help you decide.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That’s not... I just wanted to - Her mask begins slipping, why is she there?

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess I thought if I heard from you what they were... why... it might make it easier... Or. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) It’s not going to be easy.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I keep hoping. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I ask you - we’ve been friends a long time.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: Yes. She steels herself to ask this tough question.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Well, I just... you knew Don was volunteering for the Army. Why - how - how could you not tell me? Or Phil? How could you just let him... With everything that you knew... ? McNamara’s eyes are on the table, unmoving. She’s well composed, not overtly emotional. She just wants an answer

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suppose you couldn’t have told me but, I can’t help thinking... Kay watches him, seeing that she’s upset him.  75.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s alright. Nevermind. He’s home - we don’t have to -

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: No. I - I just wish I could tell you that I... He trails off.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We made mistakes. All of us. It doesn’t excuse - nothing could but... well. He takes a moment, gathering his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe we did the right thing. Maybe we didn’t. Who knows. Maybe it’s your job, the job of the press to... I don’t know. Keep us all honest? I’m not so sure if people should know everything. But I... I’m not sure anyone has a right to make that decision for them. She thinks.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (soft) I’m not sure I can.

dialogues.speaker: MCNAMARA
dialogues.text: Can or not, I think you’re going to have to decide one way or the other. She nods. Still so unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg, Geyelin and the lawyers continue to sift through the documents in a tense peace. New at the table is CHALMERS ROBERTS (60s, big ears, Chief Diplomatic Correspondent). voices in the library can be faintly heard.

dialogues.speaker: CHALMERS
dialogues.text: (annoyed) You guys couldn’t have called me any earlier?  76.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: We just got the papers, Chal.

dialogues.speaker: CHALMERS
dialogues.text: Mmhm He reads, shaking his head at what he’s reading.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Why would the Director of the CIA send a memo on war policy?

dialogues.speaker: GEYELIN
dialogues.text: Because they weren’t calling it a war yet.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: But they’re bombing -

dialogues.speaker: CHALMERS
dialogues.text: (to himself) I was supposed to retire on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Good luck with that. The front door opens and Fritz walks in. He looks to the table of weary Post employees.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Mr. Beebe, they’re -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard and Meg wince, Chalmers chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (forcing a smile) I think I’1l find my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee paces, Bagdikian has a fresh drink.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Look, I understand that you’re worried about -  77.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: - the exposure and the perception of the paper -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s exactly what - There’s a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: Fritz enters —

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: I hate to barge in. Clark stands and shakes Fritz’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Mr. Beebe, we’re trying to explain. Fritz walks over to Bradlee and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: You look terrible.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s what I was going for.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (to Bagdikian) You alright? Bagdikian shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: He’s fine. Bradlee’s hackles are up - with Fritz here he knows there no more messing around. Fritz takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: You want to catch me up, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Sure. They say we can’t, I say we can. You’re caught up.  78.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (to Clark) Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Ignoring the fact that the documents could be represented as stolen property and therefore -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: We didn’t steal anything.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: But they were -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Not by -

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Regardless of that. And forgetting that we don’t know what is going to happen with The Times case -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What’s going to happen is - Fritz puts up his hand for a second, Bradlee stops.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: As I said. Forgetting all of that. We simply don’t have the time to vet these documents. The majority of what we’re dealing with is classified information and we don’t know what’s in them. I don’t understand why it isn’t the most prudent to simply wait and ask -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (bursting) Because we lost! Fritz looks at him, the lawyers watch. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Why can’t we wait? Because we've already waited three months and four days longer than we should’ve. We’ve got egg on our face and unless we publish these documents right now we might as well be some shitty, one stoplight, no radio town, single edition paper. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are the Washington Post. We aren’t anyone’s runner-up. Fritz thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (to Bradlee) The Post is going public next week. Bagdikian looks up - surprised. Bradlee is disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our IPO is contingent on a series of steps and markers that will ensure to the -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: How’s it going to look when the biggest property in the company goes down because they didn’t have the balls to stand up with the Times.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: It’s not always about winning, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (indignant) Yes, it is! With this? It is entirely about winning. I don’t care what’s in those papers and I don’t care who we make look bad! We’re printing them and -

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: That’s not your decision. A tense beat. Bradlee hates that Fritz is right.

dialogues.speaker: ASSAYE
dialogues.text: I have an idea.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Oh, goodie.

dialogues.speaker: ASSAYE
dialogues.text: What if we wait. Hold off on printing today - Bradlee starts to interject, Assaye speaks over him -  80. ASSAYE (CONT’D) And, instead, we call the Attorney General and tell them that we intend to print the papers on Sunday. That way we give them, and ourselves, time to figure out the legality of it all. Let the courts decide what will happen with the Times. Just - give ourselves some breathing room. Bagdikian, Fritz, and Bradlee stare at him. Clark keeps h head down. A long moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (sotto) You want to... tell the Attorney General that we... have these documents and are going to print them. In a few days.

dialogues.speaker: ASSAYE
dialogues.text: (less sure) Yes. Bradlee looks back at Bagdikian, then Fritz.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s the shittiest idea I’ve ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Ben - Bradlee walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You know what? Hang on, let me go talk to my eleven-year-old and see if she has a better plan. He leaves, slamming the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay sits at the vanity, clipping large pearls to her ears Music can be heard from downstairs, the party winding up. is the consummate hostess and tonight will be no differen But her mind is elsewhere.  81. INT. PHIL’S OFFICE, GRAHAM HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Kay stands in the doorway, her hand on the light switch. After a moment, she turns the light off and closes the do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay greets various GUESTS while WAITERS distribute small bites, a glass of champagne in everyone’s hand. Kay tease and laughs, her best party face on. Every now and then sh flicks her eyes to the telephone - waiting.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Having a nice time? Ignatius stands there, martini in hand. Kay forces a smil

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Bittersweet.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Retirement parties tend to be tinged with it.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Oh, is that what this is?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Did you not see it on the invitation?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I received one. Kay absorbs the jab, forcing that smile again. She makes move to leave, he subtly cuts her off. Entertaining him i not a task she needs right now. IGNATIUS (CONT’D) I hope you weren’t offended by what I said in the board room.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (tense) Offended isn’t the word I’d use.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: However you might feel, I hope you know - I’ve always been impressed by you.  82.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: (genuine, condescending) Surprising as it may seem to hear it. The way you stood by Phil during everything. Even when he, well, I guess there’s no need to walk on a dead man’s name. Is he serious? IGNATIUS (CONT’D) I never met him, you know, but I always though we’d get along. And the way you handled yourself during his - situation - with such... style. However all of this works out - I want you to know that I have the best intentions towards -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (irate but calm) Mr. Ignatius, this really isn’t the time or place for the type of conversation you’re wading into. But I can assure you, I am well aware of your intentions - good or otherwise. (beat) Enjoy the party. She walks away, leaving Ignatius taken aback. Kay fumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee sits and watches Marina and a FRIEND (10) play in backyard. He watches but he’s not really there. A coffee is placed in front him, he looks up and sees Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Looked like you needed a pick-me- up. He nods and accepts it, she sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You give it the good stuff?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The staff drank us out of everything.  83.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Could’ve guessed that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But your daughter made a killing with her lemonade business. Bradlee smiles. Tony watches him. As much as she doesn’t to sometimes - she cares about this guy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) They’re idiots. All they can see are dollar signs vanishing in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Have you tried to convince -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Of course I have.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You sure? All I heard was a lot of “me” and “the paper” and —

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (scowling) Tony -

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Did you try and tell them what the point of it all is?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The point of it? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’1ll never understand how you convinced people you were so perceptive.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What do you -

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Did you even read -  84. But they’re interrupted with Bagdikian walking out - he l panicked.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Ben? Beebe - Fritz - he just left.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What? Where’d he -

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: To the Graham house. Bradlee grits his jaw, running into the house.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: But I have to tell you - Bradlee doesn’t hear anything - his rage overwhelming. To just watches him go. As she always does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee storms in and grabs the phone. He dials. The remaining editors and lawyers keep their heads down in th living room, trying to power through.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: Ben. Bradlee raises his hand. The phone rings. BAGDIKIAN (CONT’D) He went to tell her we can’t publish.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (hushed) No, Ben. It’s because of Ellsberg.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Nobody’s answering. What’re you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: He wanted to know if we had the same source as the Times and -  85.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, this is Ben Bradlee, I’m looking for -

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: He says -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (growing frustrated) I understand that it’s a party, but I promise that she -

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (shouting) He says we can be charged with conspiracy to commit treason! That gets the attention of everyone. Geyelin rises from h chair, the lawyers survey the room.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: They could argue that we knew that because it’s the same source as The Times, we knew we were getting stolen documents. I - I don’t know. I had one too many to catch it all -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Shit. He hangs up the phone and grabs his keys.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (sotto) She's probably too busy rubbing elbows to even know what’s going on. Bradlee stops and grits his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Enough! The volume startles everyone, Tony pokes her head in from outside.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Ben, it was just -  86.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No! I’ve heard - you have no idea what that woman is dealing with! What she’s been through! The pressure that we - you should just - He stops himself, getting blank stares. He shakes his hea

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should just be... better. He walks out, his staff left both confused and hanging th heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HONOREE (60s) speaks to the crowd, Kay stands to the side, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: HONOREE
dialogues.text: Many of you are too young to remember Mr. Meyer so, I’1l just leave you with this. Remember that this... this was a man’s life. This paper. And he did it all for the public. For the readers. He never wanted anything in return, I mean, he sunk so much money into it those early years, you’d a thought he was trying to marry it. Laughs abound. Kay digests these words. Fritz walks in an makes eye contact with Kay. She’s slightly concerned by h arrival. Ignatius spots him, too.

dialogues.speaker: HONOREE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he believed it was his duty, his public service, to put out the paper every day. Give people a chance to read the news. Bradlee runs in. A few guests notice, shooting him wary looks. Bradlee pants, beads of sweat rolling down his temples. He spots Fritz and approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You're not talking to her without me.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Ben -  87. Ignatius approaches -

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Mr. Bradlee - are you... alright?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (panting) I had to run. Who are you? Ignatius goes to speak but Kay approaches, interrupting t She gives Bradlee a once over.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: If we could take this outside. They follow her, including Ignatius, which surprises both Fritz and Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee, Fritz, and Ignatius fight it out. Kay sits nearb listening and seemingly ignored by the three men. She tak it all in.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: It’s not just that the offering can be suspended, but also the government might have just cause to seek a criminal indictment.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Don’t be dramatic.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: A felon may not hold a broadcast license, which means they will seize all of our broadcast properties. Without that revenue, we'll be forced to sell. If they win, and we are convicted, then The Washington Post Company will cease to exist.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If we’re living in a world where the government can tell you what to print and broadcast then that license doesn’t mean shit any way.  88.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: That’s just -

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: How is this even a debate? We can’t possibly risk -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If we don’t publish, we’ll be out of business soon enough as it is!

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: How -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Because The New York Times will win! Maybe not tomorrow, or next week, but gradually people will stop thinking The Post has a leg to stand on.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Ben, I understand that this might be difficult to understand -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Your patronizing tone aside, this isn’t -

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: This is about your ego? Mr. Bradlee, I truly don’t - Bradlee tries to ignore Ignatius but it’s difficult.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Look. I understand that the public offering is important. I understand that being convicted felons isn’t high on everyone’s list. But in this case it’s better than failure!

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: You and I have very differing opinions on failure.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (finally) I’m not talking to you! Ignatius is taken aback. He hates reporters.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: There will be other fights. Other -  89.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You want to talk about a court battle? If they start fighting back with freedom of the press - which they absolutely will - and it comes out that we had these documents and didn’t publish them or stand with The Times - at best we’1l look like we're scared. At worst it’ll seem like the government is telling us what we can and can’t print!

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Publishing these documents could destroy this paper.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: There’s more than one way to do that and you’re just letting them have it! We’re not even going to push back a little? What are you so scared of?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: It’s my job to -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s not your job! It’s hers! He points to Kay. They all look to her, she seems tiny compared to the three of them. They wait for her to speak Beat. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It... it is Mr. Beebe’s job to -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No. It’s yours to make this decision. Just you. BRADLEE (CONT’D) You could've told me to get off the story. But you didn’t. You could’ve told me to not get the documents. But you didn’t. BRADLEE (CONT’D) And if The Post doesn’t publish these papers, you'll have to finda new executive editor tomorrow.  90.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (scowling) Don’t be dramatic. Bradlee’s eyes don’t leave Kay’s.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You're willing to stand by that?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Absolutely. She thinks, not taking this decision lightly.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: While you may feel responsible to act as an exemplification for freedom of the press, Mr. Bradlee, I have a commitment to the thousands of people employed by this company. This isn’t their crusade and I refuse to put them in jeopardy over a... vendetta. Bradlee is crest-fallen, Ignatius heaves a sigh of relief She looks to where her granddaughter spun in the sunshine just days ago - lost in the memory for a moment. Finally, stands.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But - Bradlee perks up.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I also have a responsibility to the public. To the readers. Even when it might not support our own best interests. (beat) They lied. All of them. They lied and told us that what we were doing was good. That we were helping people who couldn’t help themselves. But that wasn’t it at all. No one wanted us there. So, they, we, just sent a bunch of young men to die. It wasn’t just my son, or your son, that they sent over there. And it shouldn’t just be us to know the truth.  gl. She stands her ground, Fritz can’t help but be moved. Kay looks to Bradlee, softening.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They knew it was wrong. Our... our friends knew. And they didn’t care. Bradlee stares at her - the weight of it all hangs betwee them. She catches herself in the emotion straightens hers back out.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you guarantee me that we can go to print without publishing the names of anyone in danger?

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Ignatius, I’m -

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: You can’t be actually considering this! This is just your maternal -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Ignatius - Ignatius turns to Fritz.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: You're just going to let her do this? She can’t possibly -

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: I assure you, this is entirely Mrs. Graham's decision. Ignatius stammers. Kay hides a smile, looking back to Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I give you my word. She thinks again, then looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Do it. Print them.  92. She turns and walks back into the party, going back to ho as if nothing happened. Bradlee can hardly believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee leans on a wall with a coffee and watches a POST TRUCK deliver stacks of newspapers. The early morning COMMUTERS begin to grab them. No one picks up The Times. Bradlee smiles and, after a moment, walks over and picks up himself. He reads the front page: “DOCUMENTS REVEAL U. EFFORT IN ‘54 TO DELAY VIET ELECTIONS - FIRST OF A SERIES CHALMERS ROBERTS”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEN and WOMEN, young and old, pick up copies of the Washington Post. They read it at NEWSTANDS and BARBER SHO STUDENTS read it on CAMPUS. There is an overwhelming feel of anger and disappointment in the faces of the readers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual cacophony of typewriters and go-getters rushes through the giant room. Gene is in his office. Howard sip coffee - his eyes glued to the glass wall of Bradlee’s of where Fritz, Kay, and Bradlee sit inside. Meg approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: They’re going to catch you staring.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Then he shouldn’t have made it a glass wall.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (smiling) Chalmers onto the next piece?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (nodding) He’s got Murrey working on one too.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Think we'll get to print them?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I’m shocked she let us get one in.  93. INT. BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - SAME TIME An awkward silence hangs between Bradlee, Kay, and Fritz who has a legal pad on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You're sure they’re going to call.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I met the AAG once. Tiny hands. Kay hides a smile. After a few moments of unbearable silence... the phone at Cynthia’s desk rings. After a mom

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s the Assistant Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Put him through. Bradlee takes a deep breath, Kay doesn’t know what to exp Bradlee’s phone rings and he puts it on speaker. BRADLEE (CONT’D) This is Bradlee. I have Mrs. Graham and Mr. Beebe here with me.

dialogues.speaker: BALILES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good morning, this is Assistant Attorney General Gerald Baliles.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Baliles. Fritz begins making notes.

dialogues.speaker: BALILES
dialogues.text: (rote) Mr. Bradlee, I have been advised by the Secretary of Defense that the material published in The Washington Post this morning contains information relating to the national defense of the United States and bears a top-secret classification. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BALILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As such, the publication of this information is directly prohibited by the provision of the Espionage Law, Title 18, United States Code, Section 793. Fritz closes his eyes tight. Kay and Bradlee exchange a glance. BALILES (0.S.) (CONT’D) Moreover, further publication will cause irreparable injury to the defense interest of the United States. Accordingly, I respectfully request that you publish no further information of this character and advise me that you have made arrangements for the return of these documents to the Department of Defense. Bradlee looks to Fritz who gives him another nod of the h

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Thank you for the call, Mr. Baliles, but we respectfully decline.

dialogues.speaker: BALILES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank you for your time. The call ends. The moment hangs there briefly.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: What’s next? Fritz sighs and stands.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: We’re going to court. Today. They’11 try and prove we knowingly published something that was a danger to the US government.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Did he call us spies?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Not as glamorous as you thought, is it. (beat) I’1l call when I have more news. For now... keep them writing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’ve opened the door. No reason closing it until they order us to.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Will it come to that?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Most assuredly. (to Bradlee) You wanted a fight. Fritz leaves, she looks at Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Bradlee?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (in a daze) Hm?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: When was the last time you slept?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The day before I started this job. Beat. Bradlee wonders why she’s still there. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Mrs. Graham?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I spoke to Mr. McNamara.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (surprised) What? You - will he -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: He’s not a villain.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be a villain to do villainous things.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: He won’t be a source for you.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Mrs. Graham -  96.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (standing) I think I’11 go with Fritz to the hearing.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: They probably won’t let you in. Why did you tell me if you’re not going to let me -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Because I didn’t want you to think I was afraid to ask. He’s stunned by this. A moment hangs between them.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll keep you informed. He nods and she leaves. He looks out to the bullpen and watches his staff; their never-ending hustle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay paces outside of a courtroom - a closed hearing takin place. She’s alone, walking up and down the hallway, her heels echoing off the walls. A YOUNG WOMAN (late 20s) hur down the hallway, part walk/part run. She’s about to open door to the courtroom -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t do that. It’s a closed hearing.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Shoot. Have they been in there for long?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (checking her watch) A few hours.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Shoot, shoot. She presses her ear to the door, Kay watches her from the corner of her eye. Finally, the young woman sits.  97. YOUNG WOMAN (CONT’D) I was supposed to bring something to my boss but I had to finish up a few things and there was so much traffic and I - well - you just wouldn’t think - at this time of night. Kay nods once, trying not to get involved. A moment passe They woman gives Kay a once over. YOUNG WOMAN (CONT’D) Are you... Mrs. Graham?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (forcing a smile) I think we’re supposed to keep our voices down. The young woman nods. Another moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: (hushed) I’m probably not supposed to say this, but I hope you win. Kay looks at her, a strange expression on her face. YOUNG WOMAN (CONT’D) I mean, I think what you’re doing - printing those papers - I think it’s right. It’s the right thing to do. Kay nods once. The woman waits a minute but can’t help herself - YOUNG WOMAN (CONT’D) I read that interview you did and - I know people been giving you a hard time but - I think you gotta just ignore them. It’s not easy being the only one of us in a room with a bunch of them. She gestures her head towards the door. YOUNG WOMAN (CONT’D) Sometimes people don’t appreciate how much you’re doing until you’ve already done it. And I like seeing someone tell these guys what’s what. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG WOMAN (CONT’D) But don’t tell my boss I said that - he'd fire me just for talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Let’s not have that happen. The woman nods and goes back to sitting there in silence. realizes she might have been rude.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. The woman offers a friendly smile, JUST as the doors to t courtroom open. Kay stands, Fritz walks over - there’s a frenzy coming from all the lawyers as they spill out.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: They’re issuing a restraining order until we can get back in to see the judge.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: (tired) Monday. And if that doesn’t work for them, we'll head to the Supreme Court of Appeals.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (angry) | We can’t print anything?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Not after tonight. But, it’s not over yet. Kay watches behind Fritz as the young woman is berated by GOVERNMENT LAWYER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee walks in disheveled, exhausted. He drops his briefcase on the ground and stands there for a moment. Enjoying the quiet. He hears the faint sound of a TV.  99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marina is asleep in front of the TV. He smiles. He moves turn it off but sees that it’s special news program on Vietnam produced by ECO. He sits for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL
dialogues.text: “... The truth of the matter is, the Paris Peace Talks, hailed as a major breakthrough in 1968 have, by 1971 achieved nothing. The delegates still turn up, make accusatory speeches and leave. Week in week out, the delegates play their parts but its all become a puppet show without an audience. And in the meantime, the war goes on and the casualty lists mount...” Bradlee grits his jaw as he watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony sits on a stool, painting in splattered overalls. A record player plays softly, a cigarette smokes in an asht Bradlee walks towards the studio with a beer. Eventually leans on the doorway. She knows he’s there but she doesn’ need to acknowledge it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I thought that one was finished.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're thinking of a different one.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Oh. Their conversation is slow. At ease. He walks to the worn recliner he sat in for many nights in the early days of t marriage. Now, it’s cluttered with papers. He moves them and sits. BRADLEE (CONT’D) Your daughter snuck down to watch TV again. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You look terrible.  100.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (smiling) So I’ve been told. He watches her paint. The sounds from the record playing between them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fritz thinks it’s going to go to the Supreme Court.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That’s what you wanted, right?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yea, I - He trails off.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I think I messed this one up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Just because you might not win doesn’t mean you messed up. Not everything is supposed to go your way, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do you? Maybe he doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If this goes bad they’re going to put the blame on me. I guess... I just don’t know if it was worth it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don’t be an idiot, Bradlee. He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yea, maybe you won’t win. Maybe you'll have to resign and start all over again. But you did the right thing. That’s worth it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Besides, you asked for the blame in the first place. You can’t put that on anyone else now that you’re up shit’s creek.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (smiling) You sure know how to cut to the quick.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Of course. It’s why you married me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Ah, is that why, I keep forgetting. It’s a joke, but there’s some truth to it. He watches her again - lost in thought. BRADLEE (CONT’D) What do you think of her?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Who? Our daughter?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (laughing) No, Mrs. Graham.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t know her.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s never stopped you from having an opinion before. She takes her time with it, turning to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I think... she’s in a position she never thought she’d have and I’m sure plenty of people don’t think she should be in. If I were her... I wouldn’t even know where to start.  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copies of The Washington Post are dropped. Each headline details the progress that’s been made on the case: “GESEL UPHOLDS PREVIOUS RULING IN ‘PENTAGON PAPERS’ CASE, APPEAL HEADED TO FEDERAL COURT”, “COURT FINDS IN FAVOR OF POST, RESTRAINING ORDER UPHELD”, “TIMES AND POST CASES ENJOINED CASE HEADED TO SUPREME COURT”, “SUPREME COURT HEARING ON ‘PENTAGON PAPERS’ SET FOR EMERGENCY SATURDAY HEARING”. IGNATIUS slams each paper onto the table. Kay watches patiently from her normal seat; Fritz looks on. The past has taken a toll. They look exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: And now our IPO is being reconsidered. A murmur amongst the board members.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: They’re just doing their due diligence. This is a big offering.

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Due diligence?

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Yes, Paul. And what is it -

dialogues.speaker: IGNATIUS
dialogues.text: Please don’t ask what I’m insinuating. I think it’s clear: ever since Mrs. Graham took over we have seen not only a steady decline in profits but, now, a jump off the cliff! Kay lets it happen - but she’s not happy about it. IGNATIUS (CONT’D) I was brought here because of my experience and never have I seen such a disregard for the best intentions of a company. If I offer my opinion and it is ignored once, I’ll let it go. Twice, I’1l raise my hand. Three times - I must speak! If no one else will, I will stand up for the interests of our Board. That’s a dagger to Kay’s heart. Fritz surveys the room, h can’t tell whose side the boardmembers are on.  103. IGNATIUS (CONT’D) Mrs. Graham, your decision to allow The Post to become involved in this crusade is beyond reprehensible. You've repeatedly allowed Mr. Bradlee and his - group - to have his way with this paper. Through weak and misguided leadership. And, frankly, it is something I am sure that neither your father, nor your husband - She stands, surprising everyone - not the least of which, herself.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That will be quite enough. It is perfectly clear, Mr. Ignatius, that you and I have very different opinions of how to run this company. However, whether you agree with my decisions or not, I have made them. Not you. Ignatius is almost red with anger.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If it is your intention to bully me into leaving this company, I assure you - that is not going to happen. If you truly believe that the correct step is for me to step down, please - take a vote. But I recommend you do it after the hearing tomorrow. You may not think I know much, but I can tell you your headline will sell much better if you fire a felon. Not just a woman. (beat) And I hate to disappoint you, Mr. Ignatius, but Phil Graham never cared for bullies and he wouldn’t have cared for you. She leaves the room, emboldened. The boardmembers shocked INT. GENE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - DAY Bradlee knocks, Gene looks up.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You got a minute?  104.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Sure. Bradlee walks in and shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You coming to the hearing tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I think I should probably stay here. In case the world decides to keep rotating while you’re all in court. Bradlee laughs once.

dialogues.speaker: GENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: No... I - I need to ask a favor.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: (joking) Hang on, let me write this down. Bradlee’s mood is serious, Gene’s expression changes. GENE (CONT’D) Jesus, Ben. What?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: If this thing goes bad. Which... I don’t know. I thought it would be over by now and it’s not so -

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: They’re just -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: When Fritz Beebe tells you it doesn’t look good... it doesn’t do much to bolster confidence. (beat) If I have to resign, if it comes to that, I need you to stay. Gene is stunned. A moment hangs between them.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s about the last thing I ever thought I’d hear.  105.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Howard’s going to want the job and if I’m here he’1ll get it. But if things go south and I have to leave - I need you to be here. They’11 listen to you and I - look, I may not have done a lot around here but... I assembled a great newsroom. I need you to keep them together for as long as you can. Gene thinks a minute.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: (quiet) Alright. Bradlee stands and offers his hand, Gene rises and takes

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: But if this goes your way I’m still getting the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (smiling) I'd expect nothing less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay sits at the table, writing in a notepad, she keeps scribbling things out. Frustrated. A half-empty glass of next to her. She hears the front door open and turns to l concerned. Lally walks in, looking exhausted. Solemn.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (concerned) Lally?

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I didn’t call. She sits across from her mother.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (carefully) Is everything OK? Where’s Katharine?  106.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: With Yann. I just... I needed to get away for a bit. Kay goes to the cabinet and gets a glass for Lally. Then pours a hefty one, surprising her daughter. Lally looks a the notepad, confused -

dialogues.speaker: LALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’re you - It dawns on her.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The case - I didn’t -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It’s alright. I’m not getting anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: You have to make a statement?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Fritz thinks it would be best.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Oh no. Honestly, I’m not even quite sure where to begin.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry - I should’ve called - Kay waves her hand to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Growing up, we always had to be scarce. Out of sight and all. I never wanted that for my children but - now. Well. It’s quiet again.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: We should visit more.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) I raised you to have your own lives. It would be hypocritical of me to ask for them back.  107.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: No it wouldn’t. You’re allowed to ask for things, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Do you? Sometimes I feel like you don’t speak up because... I don’t know. You're afraid you’1l sound -

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That’s not fair. When -

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Fair or not, it’s the truth.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: My children always think they know everything. Lally watches her mother with interest.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People thought I must have been devastated when your grandfather picked your father to run the company instead of me.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: Weren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. I was... proud. Your father was the smartest man I’d ever met. When your grandfather chose him it was like, well, it was like he chose me. Because Phil had been my choice.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: But... He didn’t choose you.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It’s different for you. Your generation - women can get away with having expectations -

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: No we can’t! But we do it because if we don’t... well. No one’s going to do it for us.  108. Kay watches her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I grew up in this house, too, Mom. Dad was smart but you... you’re the one that kept it all together. (beat) Grandpa was wrong. Kay looks down at her notepad.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I keep wandering into your father’s office. Hoping that I’1l find something new there. A journal or a letter - telling me what I’m supposed to do next. What steps to take - If I made the right ones.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: (soft) This isn’t about Dad. Or Grandpa. This is about you. And you've already done the hardest part - now you just have to stand by it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You say it as if it’s so simple.

dialogues.speaker: LALLY
dialogues.text: I know everything, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courtroom is packed, the NINE JUSTICES (all men, 40s- 60s) sit in their leather chairs and listen to the argume There are three sets of lawyers: the government (GRISWOLD 40s), the Post, and the Times. At the moment, Griswold is the lectern. Kay is in a pew directly behind Fritz, next to Lally. Ignatius is nearby. Bradlee a few behind her next to Howa He’s nervous, foot tapping on the ground. The doors open Bagdikian sneaks in, taking a seat next to Meg.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: (hushed) You see how many people are outside?  109.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (sotto) I’ve been here for the last four hours.

dialogues.speaker: GRISWOLD
dialogues.text: ... We also contend that the publishing of these documents is a dishonorable and treasonous act that will dramatically undermine the President’s power to conduct foreign affairs and in authority as Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces. Bradlee and Kay both wince at Griswold’s use of “dishonorable”. GRISWOLD (CONT’D) As the scope of these documents is so vast, it’s hard to fully warn against the consequences of them being made public. To print these papers without consulting the government is to exercise a criminal disregard for the safety of this country and our troops overseas. Griswold closes his folder and takes his seat.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE BLACK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Griswold. Now I understand that Mrs. Katharine Graham will be making a statement. Bradlee is surprised. She rises and walks to the lectern.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Judge Black. She takes a breath, steeling herself.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you said, my name is Katharine Graham and I am the owner and publisher of the Washington Post. (beat) I’ve been in the newspaper business almost my whole life. My father purchased the paper when I was sixteen and - well - all I ever wanted to do was work at it. It... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: took me a little longer than I thought it would, but, well, sometimes things happen as they should, I think. The crowd is rapt with interest.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I said, I’ve been in this business nearly my whole life and never, never, have I seen a story that displays such a wanton disregard for the public interest. To have hidden these decisions made without the people’s knowledge that resulted in decades of torture, murder, and oppression. Bradlee is stunned by the power of her words.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My father, when he stepped down, issued a press release. He said, “The citizens of a free country have to depend on a free press for the information necessary to the intelligent discharge of their duties of citizenship. That is why the Constitution gives newspapers express protection from Government interference.” It... it might have taken me a little while longer than my father would’ve hoped to truly understand these words but... I believe them to be true. It is my responsibility to stand behind my staff and the truth of their convictions to tell this story. It is our duty. Meg and Howard are rapt with attention. A shock to them b

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This paper has been in my life longer than most of my staff has been alive. And the legacy it carries is not just my name, but my father’s name. My husband’s name. And my decision to publish these papers is one that could put into jeopardy the lot of it. She almost looks back at Bradlee, but keeps her eyes forw  111.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, if the decision is made by the courts to side with the government, and the Washington Post ceases to exist, I can think of no stronger mark to leave than by taking a stand for what is right. And there will have been no greater honor in my life than to be beside the men and women of the Post while we attempt to do just that. Her voice shakes, Bradlee’s eyes are glassy but he covers

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. She steps back to her seat, she and Bradlee avoid eye contact. Lally beams with pride.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE BLACK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attendees file out. Bradlee stands with Meg and Howar He keeps his eyes aloft, looking for Kay, not paying attention to their conversation. He can’t find her. Bagdi jogs towards them from outside.

dialogues.speaker: BAGDIKIAN
dialogues.text: There’s something you gotta see. Bradlee looks around one last time to find Kay but, if sh there, she’s lost in the sea of people. He follows the tr to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradlee, Meg, Bagdikian, and Howard step out onto the ico front steps to see a PEACE RALLY taking place. Thousands people, PICKETS in the air plastered with messages like “ MORE LIES”, “BRING OUR BOYS BACK”, and “VETERANS FOR PEAC Meg smiles and pats Bradlee on the back. He stands there, hands in pockets, watching everything that’s taken place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay sits on a bench outside of the courtroom. Her ankles crossed, posture perfect, there is an unreadable look on face. Fritz walks over.  112.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t be much longer. She nods, he goes back to the attorneys. She seems to be bit of a daze, trying to wrap her head around the magnitu of it all. The sound of shuffling feet knocks her from he thoughts. She turns, surprised to see Bradlee straighteni his tie and rushing towards her. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The verdict in yet?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. He relaxes into the bench. She studies him, he finally lo at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You didn’t think I’d leave you here with the suits.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I'ma “suit”.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Graham, you are much more than that. The faintest of smiles appears for a moment on her face. sits back in the bench. After a beat - BRADLEE (CONT’D) About yesterday -—

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Did you ever see The Vagabond King?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The one with Rita Moreno?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: My father took me to see it when it was on Broadway. I was just a little girl but I remember being so excited that he picked me to go with him. Not everyone. Just me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: He liked you.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: There’s a scene I’ve been thinking about quite a lot lately. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since Phil died, really. At the end, when the King appears in royal garb, walking down those steps for the first time. All the archers have their arrows pointed at him, ready to release at any moment - deciding what to do - deciding if... he is worthy enough to wear those robes. She trails off into the memory, choosing to keep the intention of the story private. He watches her, then -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. She looks at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: For... well. Not trusting you.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (conspiratorial grin) I didn’t trust you the whole time either, Mr. Bradlee.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Still. I was wrong. After a moment, she nods ever so slightly.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Being the victim doesn’t really suit me. All it does is open a door for more people to judge you. Criticize you. And, I guess, one day you have to just decide not to allow them to do that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Would love to know how you did that.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Sometimes in life you don’t really decide to move on, you just do. Blindly and mindlessly.  114.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Blindly and mindlessly. I like that. Next to them, the doors to the courtroom open and Fritz t to give Kay a nod. She stands, nervously smoothing her dr She walks into the courtroom first, followed closely behi by Bradlee. The doors shut. INT. BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - THE NEXT DAY The front page of the Washington Post sits on his desk. T headline reads, “SUPREME COURT RULES IN FAVOR OF PAPERS”. Bradlee looks at the famous photo of he and Kay on the st of the courthouse, celebrating their victory, a smile of pride on his face. He tears it from the rest of the paper Cynthia walks in.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: We can have an actual photo framed for you, y’know.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I like this one. Did you reach Mrs. Graham for me?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I left word. He writes on the photo, “Wear the robes - B” then hands i Cynthia. She looks at it, confused.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Make sure that gets to her desk. She nods and he rises, walking to the bullpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the center of the room, his back to the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Hey! Can I have everyone’s attention for a minute? The staff turns. Gene steps out of his office and into th doorway. Meg, Howard, Bagdikian, and Geyelin all listen f various parts of the newsroom.  115. BRADLEE (CONT’D) This is going to be quick because it takes an act of God for any of you to hit a deadline even without an interruption. Laughs from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say thank you. I - you know - I don’t say it enough but. The guts. The energy and of everyone involved in this and... well - it has impressed me more than anything. You were all beautiful. Behind him, Kay steps off the elevator. He doesn’t see he but others do. Bradlee’s voice shakes slightly. BRADLEE (CONT’D) To have been able to work beside you all, to work with our publisher who saw through the fear of retribution. Who saw the need to bring it all to light. To echo Mrs. Graham's words - to have been a part of that is one of the greatest honors of this newsman’s life. There’s a split second of awkwardness as no one knows wha do with such a level of sincerity from him. Finally, Howa begins to clap. The room applauds and cheers, after a min he waves his hands - BRADLEE (CONT’D) Alright! Enough! To work! They all listen and get to it. Bradlee makes eye contact Gene who offers a slight nod of the head before going int his office. Bradlee turns to see Kay walking in his direction. He forces a smile, slightly embarrassed. Kay approaches Bradlee. There’s a moment hanging between them

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Would you have really resigned? He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Do you think Phil would have published the Papers? After a moment. That conspiratorial grin again -  116.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Not in a million years. He laughs and they begin to walk towards his office.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If now is alright, I was hoping we could discuss the Style section? He starts to laugh, then realizes -

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You’re serious.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: We can’t sit around in sentimentality all day.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m not getting into this with you again.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Then it appears we are at an impasse.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: That’s one word for it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I’m not saying it’s entirely wrong, but the section it - it just doesn’t make sense to me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s not meant for you!

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Who’s it meant for?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) We've discussed this.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I think it deserves just another conversation —

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The Times -—

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Not with The Times again -  117. They walk into Bradlee’s office, where we stay outside in bullpen and watch through the glass. Bradlee sits, stubbo and headstrong, feet on the desk and arms in the air out exasperation. Kay, seated across from him, thoughtful but equally stubborn, politely making her point.

dialogues.text: NIXON’S RESIGNATION, AND THE END OF THE VIETNAM WAR.

dialogues.speaker: POST UNTIL 1991. HE REMAINS ONE OF THE MOST RESPECTED NEW
dialogues.text: OF THE 20TH CENTURY. BRADLEE’S TIRELESS PASSION INFLUENCE
